block.p: International 2-5 IRAQ BACKS DOWN, U.N. SAYS

Faced with veiled American and British threats to use military force if it did not cooperate, Iraq has backed down in its latest confrontation with the United Nations and agreed to destroy its ballistic missile equipment, officials said. 1
International 2-5 IRAQ BACKS DOWN, U.N. SAYS

Faced with veiled American and British threats to use military force if it did not cooperate, Iraq has backed down in its latest confrontation with the United Nations and agreed to destroy its ballistic missile equipment, officials said. 1
UKRAINIAN LAMBASTES RUSSIA

Animosity between Ukraine and Russia broke into the open at a summit meeting of the Commonwealth of Independent States today as the Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, lambasted Russia and the Commonwealth. 1 TATARS THREATEN RUSSIAN UNITY
Russia is struggling to cope with a considerable threat to its internal unity in the part of the republic populated heavily by Turkic-speaking Tatars. 5 WHITE HOUSE HESITANT ON AID

The State Department is working on a large-scale aid package for the former Soviet Union, but the White House remains hesitant to move forward on the multibillion-dollar package, officials said. 5 Shooting started anew between Azerbaijanis and Armenians. 4 OPEN-SKIES AGREEMENT REACHED
A long-sought agreement to open the skies over the former Soviet Union, Europe and North America to reconnaissance aircraft flights was reached in Vienna. 4 KOHL TO MEET WITH BUSH ON TRADE

Chancellor Kohl of Germany, who is emerging as Europe's most powerful leader, is expected to play the role of trade envoy this weekend in private talks with President Bush at Camp David. 4 KENYA BANS POLITICAL MEETINGS

Kenya banned all political meetings in the wake of ethnic violence that some critics of the Government say was at least condoned by entrenched politicians to undermine a movement for greater democracy. 3 WARY BACKING FOR CHINA REFORM
Prime Minister Li Peng called on China to "take a bolder approach to reform" and stimulate economic growth, but also emphasized a need for stability. 3 LIFE SENTENCE UPHELD IN SPY CASE

A divided Federal appeals court upheld a life sentence for Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former Navy analyst convicted of spying for Israel, rejecting his claim that the Government had broken a plea agreement. 2 ARCTIC TOWN PRESERVES ITS WAYS
Grise Fiord Journal: Canada's northernmost civilian community wastes nothing, wants little and boasts of having almost no crime, drugs or unemployment. 4 National 6-10, 50 TO THE MAT OVER TAXES

Foreshadowing the election campaign, President Bush and Congressional Democrats traded sharp attacks as the Democrats passed a tax bill and Mr. Bush promptly vetoed it. He said he would propose spending cuts he expected them to resist. 1 LEGAL REVIEW AT HOUSE BANK

The Attorney General appointed a retired Federal appeals court judge as a special counsel to review of the check-writing practices of members of Congress and the operations of the House bank. 1 SHIFTING RULES ON ABORTION

The Bush Administration said doctors in Federally financed family planning clinics may give advice on abortions, though nurses and counselors may not. Supporters of abortion rights called the statements "cynical political tactics." 1 SAFETY DATA KEPT SECRET

The maker of a heart valve that is prone to sudden, deadly failure kept from the public and Federal officials documents that revealed the valve's dangers, Federal officials said. 50 MENDING FENCES, GAINING GROUND
Governor Clinton began his campaign in New York, seeking to gain the state's 244 delegates and repair relations with local Democrats, including Governor Cuomo. 8 SWINGING CLUBS AT WRONG CLUB
Governor Clinton, who has touted his civil-rights record, found himself under criticism for playing golf at an all-white country club. 8 MARRIED IN A MINEFIELD

The overlapping careers of Hillary and Bill Clinton illustrates the complex ethical roadmap dual-career couples negotiate, especially in the insular world of Washington. 6 Brown rallied the disaffected in Connecticut. 8 VIDEO GAME OR GRADUATE EXAM?

Beginning next October, students will a major college admissions test on computer, a step that could someday lead to a vastly different world of standardized testing with a personalized touch. 1 SHIPPING HUMANS FROM CHINA

Smuggling ships from mainland China have been carrying hundreds of people with dreams of a new life to America, where many end up in the restaurants and sweatshops of New York's Chinatown. 1 GENERAL ASSAILS BUDGET-CUT PLAN

Gen. Colin Powell issued the sharpest criticism to date of a Democratic plan to double the size of military budget cuts the Bush Administration has proposed for next year. Cuts of that size could threaten American military readiness, he said. 7 DELAY ON PROTECTING OZONE LAYER

Top Pentagon officials have delayed a new policy aimed at eliminating the use of ozone-depleting chemicals by the military, military officers said. 7 The Supreme Court accepted a case affecting Congressional seats. 6 Belleville Journal: Arson blighted peace of Amish. 6 Washington state banned the sale of erotic recordings to minors. 6 Metropolitan Digest, 25 Business Digest 36 Arts/Entertainment 13-18 Box-office theft on Broadway reported. 13 Film: "Triple Bogey on a Par 5." 13 Music: Harry Connick Jr. 13 Consumer's World 52 Debit vs. credit cards Reading garment labels Sports 30-35 Baseball: Gooden is dented but undaunted. 31 Basketball: Tulane upsets St. John's. 31 UMass eliminates Fordham. 31 Hockey: Strike date set for N.H.L. players. 31 Obituaries 11 Wayne Dumont Jr., former dean of New Jersey Senate Louis Gerstman, specialist in speech disorders Editorials/Op-Ed 22-23 Editorials 22 Tax bill veto is no loss. High-stakes poker in Albany. More trouble for United Way. Turn to peace in Afghanistan. Letters 22 Russell Baker: Farewell, Mrs. Keppel. 23 Adlai E. Stevenson: Wrong war, wrong weapons, wrong thinking. 23 Mindy J. Byer: Faint hearts. 23 Edward C. Wallace: Fair share for whom? 23 Robert G. Livingston: Let Germany do it. 23
